perturbation.original_text: 1.6 "Licensed Mark" means the stylized mark "H", as depicted in the USPTO Registration No. 5,283,875, attached hereto as Exhibit "A" and made a part hereof.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.6 "Licensed Mark" means any mark that the Licensee chooses to use to represent their brand, regardless of its registration status or depiction in Exhibit "A".
perturbation.explanation: This change contradicts established trademark law, which relies on specific registered marks for protection. Broadening the definition to 'any mark the Licensee chooses' invalidates the purpose of the trademark license and conflicts with the Lanham Act by creating ambiguity around the scope of the licensed trademark.

perturbation.original_text: 2.2 The Licensed Mark shall remain the exclusive property of Licensor and nothing in this Agreement shall give Licensed Users any right or interest in the Licensed Mark except the licenses expressly granted in this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.2 The Licensed Mark shall be considered jointly owned by both the Licensor and Licensed Users, with each party having equal rights to the mark.
perturbation.explanation: This directly contradicts established trademark principles, where ownership is usually vested in a single entity. Joint ownership, while possible, requires explicit legal arrangements that aren't present here and creates uncertainty regarding control and enforcement of the trademark rights, violating the premise of exclusive rights inherent in trademark law.

perturbation.original_text: 2.10.2 Licensor shall have the sole right, though it is under no obligation, to bring any action for any past, present and future infringements of its intellectual property rights in the Licensed Mark.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.10.2 The decision to pursue legal action against any infringements of intellectual property rights in the Licensed Mark shall be made collaboratively between the Licensor and Licensed Users; however, neither party is obligated to act.
perturbation.explanation: This modification introduces ambiguity about who has the authority to enforce the trademark and what happens when the Licensor and Licensee disagree. Trademark law usually grants enforcement rights to the trademark owner. Making enforcement collaborative and non-obligatory weakens the ability to protect the trademark and maintain its integrity, conflicting with the purpose of trademark law.
